verses.text: After these acts of faithfulness, Sennacherib king of Assyria came and invaded Judah. He encamped against the fortified cities, thinking to break into them for himself.
verses.comment: Follows closely the Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: When Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib had come and intended to wage war against Jerusalem,
verses.comment: Stays literal to the original intent.

verses.text: he consulted with his officials and his mighty men about stopping the water of the springs that were outside the city, and they helped him.
verses.comment: The word 'consulted' reflects careful deliberation as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: So many people gathered together, and they stopped all the springs and the brook that flowed through the land, saying, 'Why should the kings of Assyria come and find much water?'
verses.comment: Keeps the rhetorical question found in the original.

verses.text: He also strengthened himself, rebuilt all the wall that was broken down, raised it up to the towers, and built another wall outside. He repaired the Millo in the city of David, and made large amounts of weapons and shields.
verses.comment: Retains 'Millo' as a proper name, following precedent.

verses.text: He set military commanders over the people, gathered them to him in the square at the city gate, and spoke encouragingly to them, saying,
verses.comment: 'Spoke encouragingly' matches the Hebrew phrase 'spoke to their heart.'

verses.text: 'Be strong and courageous. Do not be afraid or discouraged because of the king of Assyria or all the army that is with him, for there is a greater One with us than with him.
verses.comment: 'Discouraged' translates 'dismayed,' closer to modern idiom.

verses.text: With him is only an arm of flesh, but with us is the LORD our God to help us and to fight our battles.' The people were strengthened by the words of Hezekiah king of Judah.
verses.comment: 'Arm of flesh' is an exact phrase from Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: After this, Sennacherib king of Assyria, while he was besieging Lachish with all his forces, sent his servants to Jerusalem—to Hezekiah king of Judah and to all Judah who were in Jerusalem—saying,
verses.comment: Phrase 'all his forces' clarifies Heb. for modern readers without interpretation.

verses.text: 'This is what Sennacherib king of Assyria says: On what are you trusting, that you remain in Jerusalem under siege?
verses.comment: 'Under siege' from Heb. 'in the siege' or 'blockade.'

verses.text: Isn't Hezekiah misleading you, so that you die by famine and thirst, saying, “The LORD our God will deliver us from the hand of the king of Assyria?”
verses.comment: Translates 'die by famine and thirst' as per literal Heb.

verses.text: Has not this same Hezekiah taken away His high places and His altars, saying to Judah and Jerusalem, “You shall worship before one altar and burn incense on it?”
verses.comment: Retains singular 'one altar' matching Hebrew.

verses.text: Do you not know what I and my fathers have done to all the peoples of other lands? Were the gods of the nations of those lands able to deliver their lands from my hand?
verses.comment: 'Were the gods... able...' matches Hebrew syntax.

verses.text: Who among all the gods of those nations that my fathers destroyed has been able to deliver his people from my hand, that your God should deliver you from my hand?
verses.comment: Literal rendering with rhetorical question structure.

verses.text: Now therefore, do not let Hezekiah deceive you or persuade you like this, and do not believe him. For no god of any nation or kingdom has been able to deliver his people from my hand or the hand of my fathers. How much less will your God deliver you from my hand!'
verses.comment: Finishes Sennacherib's blasphemous taunt as in Hebrew.

verses.text: His servants spoke even more against the LORD God and against His servant Hezekiah.
verses.comment: 'Spoke even more' translates Heb. 'spoke still more words.'

verses.text: He also wrote letters to insult the LORD, the God of Israel, and to speak against Him, saying, 'Just as the gods of the nations of the other lands have not delivered their people from my hand, so the God of Hezekiah will not deliver His people from my hand.'
verses.comment: 'Insult' translates Heb. 'to reproach/blaspheme.'

verses.text: They called out with a loud voice in the language of Judah to the people of Jerusalem who were on the wall, to frighten and terrify them, in order to capture the city.
verses.comment: 'Language of Judah' translates Hebrew 'Yehudit.'

verses.text: They spoke of the God of Jerusalem as though He were like the gods of the peoples of the earth, the work of human hands.
verses.comment: Retains Hebraic formula 'work of hands of man.'

verses.text: But King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz prayed about this and cried out to heaven.
verses.comment: 'Cried out' matches original Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: Then the LORD sent an angel, who destroyed every mighty warrior, commander, and officer in the camp of the king of Assyria. So he returned in shame to his own land. When he entered the house of his god, those of his own descendants killed him there with the sword.
verses.comment: Translates theological term 'angel' exactly; 'in shame' as per Heb.

verses.text: So the LORD saved Hezekiah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem from the hand of Sennacherib king of Assyria and from the hand of all others, and guided them on every side.
verses.comment: 'Guided them on every side' matches idiom for security.

verses.text: Many brought gifts to the LORD at Jerusalem and precious things to Hezekiah king of Judah, so that he was exalted in the eyes of all nations from that time on.
verses.comment: Literal rendering of exaltation among nations.

verses.text: In those days Hezekiah became mortally ill, and he prayed to the LORD. He spoke to him and gave him a miraculous sign.
verses.comment: 'Miraculous sign' translates Heb. 'sign.'

verses.text: But Hezekiah did not respond with thankfulness for the benefit given to him, because his heart was proud; therefore wrath came upon him and upon Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.comment: 'Did not respond with thankfulness' literal of Heb. 'did not return according to the benefit.'

verses.text: But Hezekiah humbled himself for the pride of his heart—he and the inhabitants of Jerusalem—so that the wrath of the LORD did not come upon them in the days of Hezekiah.
verses.comment: Phrase matches Hebrew idiom closely.

verses.text: Hezekiah had very great riches and honor. He made treasuries for silver, for gold, for precious stones, for spices, for shields, and for all kinds of valuable items.
verses.comment: Renders 'spices' and 'shields' clearly as per the text.

verses.text: He made storehouses for the harvest of grain, wine, and oil, and stalls for all kinds of livestock, and pens for flocks.
verses.comment: Translated literally, modern terms for produce.

verses.text: He built cities for himself, and acquired flocks and herds in abundance, for God had given him very great wealth.
verses.comment: Emphasizes God's role in his prosperity.

verses.text: This same Hezekiah stopped the upper outlet of the waters of Gihon and directed them down to the west side of the city of David. Hezekiah succeeded in all his works.
verses.comment: Literal; preserves 'Gihon' as proper name.

verses.text: However, when the ambassadors of the princes of Babylon were sent to him to ask about the sign that had occurred in the land, God left him, to test him, that He might know all that was in his heart.
verses.comment: 'God left him, to test him' follows original construction.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Hezekiah, and his deeds of faithfulness, are written in the vision of the prophet Isaiah son of Amoz, in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.comment: 'Acts of faithfulness'—literal of Heb. 'acts of kindness/faithfulness.'

verses.text: Hezekiah slept with his fathers, and they buried him in the upper section of the tombs of the sons of David; all Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem honored him at his death. And Manasseh his son became king in his place.
verses.comment: 'Slept with his fathers' matches the Hebraic euphemism for death.
